_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC operates as an ethanol fuel production plant located in the city of Madera, in Madera County, California.  As a requirement of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and Clean Air Act Amendments 112; Accidental Release of Hazardous Air Substances program, Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC completed a risk management plan (RMP) for chemicals stored on-site above RMP reporting thresholds. Regulated chemicals at Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC include isopentane and pentane  (each exceed 10,000 pound threshold).



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol production process.  It is the policy of Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  In the event of an emergency, including an accidental release of toxics and flammables, it is the policy of Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC to notify the Madera Fire Department and the Madera County Sheriff Department and evacuate all employees at the facility.  



Regulated Substances Handled

The facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn and a process by-product known as wet distillers' grain with solubles, which is used as a livestock feed. The fuel ethanol production process requires use of a denaturant (natural gasoline) which may contain approximately 24 percent pentane and approximately 21 percent isopentane, both RMP-regulated substances.  The maximum amount of denaturant on-site is approximately 180,000 pounds (total pentane approximately 42,000 pounds; total isopentane approximately 37,000 pounds).  Unleaded fuel may also be used as a denaturant in place of natural gasoline and does not contain any regulated constituents above the threshold quantity.  Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC has evaluated the worst-case and alternative case scenarios as they relate

to the regulated substances.  An Emergency Response Program (Integrated Contingency Plan, or ICP) for these scenarios has been prepared and implemented. Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC has coordinated emergency response with the local authorities and will conduct periodic drills.  



General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Through completion of this RMP, Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC has complied with the EPA requirements under 40 CFR Part 68 and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements, as well as California regulations at CCR Title 8, Section 5189 and CCR Title 19 D-2, Chapter 4.5.  Process safety information, safe work practices such as Hot Work, Confined Space Entry and Lockout/Tagout, and operations and maintenance procedures are documented on-site as part of the facility PSM/RMP Prevention Program.  Periodic functions such as process hazard analysis, training, management of change, pre-startup safety reviews, and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis as outlined in the PSM/RMP Prevention Program.  Audits of the overall RMP and Prevention Program are conducted on a regular basis.

 

Five Year Accident History

Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC does not have a history of accidents related to RMP-regulated programs which may have caused death, injuries, environmental or property damage, evacuations or in-place sheltering in the last five years.  The facility commenced operation on October 31, 2006.



Emergency Response Program

Pacific Ethanol Madera, LLC is included in the community emergency response plan and has developed their own written emergency response plan (ICP).  This plan includes actions to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances, actions to inform the public and local agencies responding to accidental releases and emergency health care information.  Pacific Ethanol Madera has provided a copy of the ICP to the Madera Fire Department and the Madera County Environmental Health Department. Pacific Ethanol Madera,

LLC conducts routinely employee training on the ICP and periodically evaluates the plan for necessary revisions.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Pacific Ethanol Madera presented a number of recommendations to improve facility safety as part of its original RMP submittal.  These recommendations have been addressed and records are maintained at the facility.  Pacific Ethanol Madera remains committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process. Management is committed to promoting a safe work environment. Pacific Ethanol Madera will continue to provide its employees with the necessary training, tools, and ongoing support needed to conduct their work safely and to operate the ethanol production process in a safe and efficient manner.
